pros:
- Salary seems to be above market, which makes sense. You gotta offer something to have someone move to such a tiny town.

- Summers are nice. It's awesome you can take summer hours and go to the lake. Although, I would not take this for granted because some business units within Whirlpool don't follow summer hours.

- You will get good experience working here and if you're liked by management, they will treat you well, accommodate to your needs and give you opportunities to grow.

- Most of the people I have interacted with were friendly and willing to help. Like most other companies, some had their own personal agenda.
cons:
- Small town. Not the best place to live unless you're looking to start a family and even then it's questionable. This makes it very hard to attract outside talent, especially young talent. 

- Their HR policies literally contradict with their values. They're all about "one whirlpool" and acting as a team, yet performance reviews are done using a forced distribution system where people are pitted against one another.

- Senior Leadership actions don't align with their words. They say one thing but do another.

- Be prepared to be doing the work of multiple people. Leadership is a big fan of attrition. 

- In the span of 3 years, I've had 6 bosses. That kind echoes all the cons I've listed. It's hard for Whirlpool to retain talent and it's also because org changes are made without any reason. 

- Whirlpool has some ridiculous processes that just add complexity for no reason. It makes driving change that much harder. Their project management process makes zero sense and their PMIS to support it is even worse.
Advice to Management
Get more input from your employees. Sometimes it feels like you're in your own bubble and don't realize the consequences of your actions.

I worked in HR and it was no secret that the company didn't like it when people had to go on a long term medical leave. I was dealing with many health issues....some that would require surgery. I lost my job 3 weeks before I would of went out on a medical leave. I ended up having 3 surgeries and a year after losing my job, I applied for SSDI. I was approved on my first try which is unheard of and instead of using the date that I actually applied, SSDI went back an entire year before and started my SSDI the date I lost my job......that NEVER happens. I had made the mistake of signing up for LTD (Long Term Disability) Insurance the year before I lost my job......what a coincidence!!

pros:
- Some of the facilities are state of the art
- The company still has a good name on the market so adding it to you resume is not so bad
cons:
- Being repetitive to what many said before, but this is really important: Leaders do not do what they say! 
- When you enter the company you are bombarded by all this information on how the company works with the highest ethical standards, its values, their focus on people development, the infamous CEO motto " there is no right way to do the wrong thing", etc. It is really impressive. You cannot avoid thinking you came to the right place! Keep your eyes and ears open, however, and after some time you will learn that most of those things are theoretical or just plain propaganda. Things are way different on the day to day. 
- It is a large corporation located in a tiny town. As a result of that, who you are friends with outside of work dictates your chances of succeeding in the company. Be friends with the right people and you can get away with just about anything
- Politics, which is a normal game in any company in the world, has reached surreal levels in the company. Being well connected and playing politics right replace being minimally competent or actually delivering minimum tangible results. In fact it is impressive the number of people around that don't do much other than showing up and opinionating without adding any value. To be fair the company tries to break this cycle by bringing people from different places, but they are smart individuals that learn fast "how things work around here" and happily join the game
- Are you a self started, highly motivated individual that wants to make a difference with your work? Shame on you! That is not what the company wants from you. What is expected is that you follow orders without questioning. In fact there are days you could as well leave your brain at home. Try to do anything different and you will upset a lot of people and end up being punished for challenging the status quo. No kidding, people can be punished for taking the right initiative, because didn't ask permission to do what he or she was hired to do in the first place.
- Words don't have the same meaning at Whirlpool as you have learned outside. "Straight talk", just to give example, actually means "keep your head down and do as you are told to". Again, keep your eyes and ears open and you will learn fast enough. Repeating to exhaustion the flavor of the month buzzwords is, however, a great way to play politics so leaders will do just that even though it does not mean anything or means just the opposite of what they practice
- The company is incredibly bureaucratic and so process driven that you spend more time dealing with the processes requirements than doing your actual work
- Reorganizations are frequent and change significantly how things are done, accountabilities, teams' composition, etc. generating a long, confusing and improductive transition period. When things are starting to work minimally well, but still with lots of room for improvement it is time to reorganize again and start all over. Reorganizations fail to address the main issue, though. Excessive bureucracy and improductive people, for example, typically remain in place. Talented people, on the other hand, frequently get frustrated and leave. Turn over in the company is high. 
- The company has a non compete agreement as a condition for employment. The agreement, introduced a few years back, was sold to employees as "a standard practice in the industry" to "protect the high investment the company made in preparing its employees" (wonder what they are talking about) and prevents you from working at any competitor for one year, if you decide to leave. It turns out none of the competitors have such "standard practice in the industry". This fact alone speaks volumes on how much you should trust the leaders in this company
- Having a non compete agreement puts you in the hands of your supervisor and they know it. They will strongly push you to resign in case they don't like you (regardless of the value you might be adding) knowing you will not be able to join the competition shortly. It happens frequently.
Helpful (9

review_title: A great company, fading down a strange path...
pros: Was a lot of fun 10 years back, great energy, innovation, creativity. Pay and benefits are good. A lot of good people at the middle and lower levels who are great to work with.
cons:
Many corporate HR policies, under the guise of being more "fair" and "caring", are rapidly undermining morale across broad swaths of the company. You can't keep cutting staff to the bone indefinitely, while adding non-value-add tasks that ultimately are only used to gather data on people to use to thin the herd the next time around (every few years). Also, the company is extremely liberal in diversity and other things, such that, if you are not LGBT, or Indian, or whatever, you better keep your mouth shut about what you might believe, as there's no room for non-conformers. I have no issue with being inclusive, and totally agree that all should feel welcome where they work, but it needs to be balanced, everyone should feel it's ok to bring "their whole self" to work.
Advice to Management
Top management doesn't seem too concerned with morale...

pros: They pay well (if you are salaried), but you will be working way more than 40 hours per week. Take that into account when you evaluate the pay.
cons:
The corporate culture at Whirlpool is poisonous. Let me translate some of their leadership model:
Own it: Anything that goes wrong, even if it is caused by changes management required or insufficient resources is YOUR fault.
One Whirlpool: You are going to get hosed in favor of other favored people and projects, but don't you dare complain about it
Lead with speed: Regardless of the fact that we are not going to give you sufficient resources and an unrealistic time table, we expect you to work 70-80 hours a week to get it done (as long as you are salied, because we will not pay overtime)

Whirlpool is a very "clique" environment, it is very difficult to come in from the outside and break into the groups that came up through Whirlpool from the start.

Their leadership model is a joke if you are a manger. I went to several classes on leadership and coaching, and had to fight back the laughter. It applies below the manager level when convenient, but directors and above feel no need to follow it.

Also, it is a very "up or out" place. Once they feel you have reached your full growth potential, your days are numbered.
Advice to Management
Get the directors and above to treat middle management like human beings. Stop reorganizing and changing processes without thought.

review_title: Good place to start your career, not a long term option
pros:
You own you're career - they will give you lots of work if you prove yourself. People are open to sharing their experiences - and it's up to you to learn and navigate through it. 
They have a great leadership program. I highly recommend anyone to try it and complete it. It'll open a world of opportunities for you.
cons:
There are some major gender inequality issues in various departments - especially the finance and accounting department (look at the leadership ratio and how it trickles down). Because of this, it can be tricky to navigate politics based on your gender, let alone get actionable feedback or be comparable to your male colleagues. The perception is that more often than not - women find themselves required to "prove" themselves prior to a promotion/pay raise while men can get this based on potential prior to proving themselves. 
After you've been there for a period of time, you'll notice you'll stop hearing what you're doing well and the focus will be more on your faults or weaknesses - and how you need to be well rounded in every facet. Depending on your career ambitions, this most likely isn't the best route. The key would be to play on your strengths and minimize your weaknesses - the opposite of what they'll want you to do. Because of this, you'll find your "own glass ceiling" within 3 years. 
Bonuses rarely are 100%. Expect your base only. 
Work life balance is terrible if you want to be successful. Within the finance function - it was very hard to find 'working families'. Almost everyone above Manager level had only one working spouse if they had kids.
Advice to Management
Keep up the leadership programs - they're great for people to start. Gender Equality is significantly lacking in certain functions. Don't choose favorites - but stick to what you preach - performance.
Helpful (3
advice_to_mgmt: Keep up the leadership programs - they're great for people to start. Gender Equality is significantly lacking in certain functions. Don't choose favorites - but stick to what you preach - performance.

Slow product development and silo'd ownership.
Advice to Management

Less focus on individual objectives, and more autonomy to the teams.
Less focus on career advancement for individuals satisfied with their roles. 
Mid level management should "Know the products".

review_title: Principal Engineer GPO - Whirlpool used to be a Great Company
pros: Good salary, benefits, work/life balance and flexible work hours. Many opportunities to learn and grow and expand your career if you choose to.
cons:
1. Unbelievable politics and hidden agendas among upper management.
2. Recent major restructure within GPO (Global Product Organization) was blatant age discrimination with very large % of those laid off in the 'over 50-highly compensated-long career employees'. Ridiculous attempt to justify the lay offs with systemic low ratings given to targeted employees over a 2 year period. Many of those 105 people laid off have compared notes and now understand the coordinated approach to this restructure and downsizing.
3. Project plans are formalized and accepted but when project is delayed for good reasons, schedule absolutely rules. Bad decisions made to move forward with production with no regard for customer perception or experience. Only goal is to sell the product. This is why competitors are beating Whirlpool. 
4. No coordinated strategic approach to product innovation and if an approach is attempted, no accountability for results.
5. Management and HR can not be trusted - beware! What you are told by either is likely in-line with hidden plans and agendas and certainly not with your best interests in mind.
Advice to Management
> Get back to the basics of really valuing employees and commitments to the end-user customer since they are the foundational principles that made Whirlpool great.
> Don't cave in to pressures from Wall Street analysts and stock holders as has been done in the recent history of the company. If this goes on, employees will continue to leave and Whirlpool will no longer be viable.
> Modernize the performance rating system as it drives dissension and distrust among employees and management.
> Be honest and up front with employees regarding RIF plans. Whirlpool truly should be ashamed of the way the Feb-March 2016 GPO RIF was implemented. Complete disregard and disrespect for many that had given the majority of their working lives to Whirlpool. SHAME ON YOU.

employee_status: Senior Engineer in Benton Harbor, MI
review_title: Great people, mediocre management and leadership
pros:
- The people at Whirlpool are its strength. Kind, engaged and helpful. 
- Leadership believes in assigning responsibilities irrespective of employee age or experience at company, which is a good and bad thing. Good because your age does not limit you from taking on responsibilities. Bad because assigning responsibilities to a new employee is not helpful if there is no mentoring to back it up.
cons:
- Leadership does not have clear direction
- Employee rating system drives unhealthy competition between employees, causing employees to be invested in making sure only their rating at the end of the year is good. 
- Marketing gets to make all the decisions, which means an employee often has no idea what his/her end-goal on a project is. 
- No work/life balance, unless the employee makes a conscious effort to maintain one, in which case, his/her employee rating suffers. Its a vicious cycle.
Advice to Management
- Invest in better people leaders and a good mentoring system
- Get rid of your employee rating system
- Think outside the box and do not just follow marketing's advice blindly.
Helpful (11
advice_to_mgmt:
- Invest in better people leaders and a good mentoring system
- Get rid of your employee rating system
- Think outside the box and do not just follow marketing's advice blindly.

pros: Highly diverse, some people are trying, offer jobs with good pay, good benefits, weekends off. Looks out for family and friends.
cons:
Small-town politics in a large company, this company use to only hire family and friends. Now we use a temp service to hire operators from everywhere and anywhere only requirement is you need a high school diploma,very high turnover. Favoritism towards seniority, and friends with a total disregard to talent, leadership skills, and abilities when it comes to hiring leaders . Leaders are more of a manager than a leader, lacking soft skills.
Advice to Management
Really need to clean house of people who don't want to change, hire people who want to be leaders . Higher for leadership qualities and not for seniority and friendship. Communicate better between lines to form plant wide best practices learn from each other don't compete with each other we have enough competitors out there we don't need internal conflict. work as a team, reward good work, team work, good behaviors and praise people in public. Make sure your operators know what you expect of them and remind them everyday. let's build leaders thru mentoring programs and holding leadership accountable for their actions by praising leaders for developing and mentoring good up-and-coming leaders.

review_title: Great company, is getting stuck into small town politics while chasing many moving targets
pros:
Wonderful people to work with, experienced, talented, you name it.
Great company to learn and grow, facing a lot of challenges and reach to expand your capabilities.
There are many different areas and brands to work, so you can get great experience.
cons:
Location - small town with all its implications
Silly politics - there is a performance review in place, but what wins is small group politics more related to friendships and power-groups that want to maintain their comfortable status quo.
Chasing many moving targets, with lots of firedrills
Advice to Management
Don't just give a number and chase it no matter what, make sure there's a uniform and solid strategy. 

Leave friends and politics outside the talent pools, that's why your employee churn rate is growing so fast.

Don't be afraid to break the status quo, that's why the competitors are winning.
